Description: Terracotta figure of Harpokrates. Harpokrates seated on the ground, his legs extending to his right, upon a curve-fronted plain plinth. He wears a long chiton with short sleeves, and his large phallus emerges from its hem to rest on the ground between his feet. His hair is long and wavy and there is a hint of a side-lock resting on his right shoulder. Two lotus buds are placed at the top of his head and flank a Double Crown, now broken. He holds a pot to his left hip and places his right hand into its mouth. The back is plain, with a circular vent. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, with traces, mainly on the front, of a white dressing.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close, probably same mould-series: Breccia 1934: no. 74 (see also pl. xxvii:124); Dunand 1979: no. 138. Near: Engelbach et al. 1915: pl. lxi:45 (very coarse, perhaps unclothed), from an ancient shop at Memphis (Petrie Museum uc8744); Laumonier 1921: no. 580. Bibliog. Fischer 1994: 269, no. 590.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3057)
